SubTopics: Write text in a variety of modes.
Content: The character of David has a function in the story “Into the Volcano.” Write an essay analyzing the important role David plays as a character throughout the passage. Use evidence from the passage to support your response.

:ibox:PLAN before you write
• Read the entire passage(s) carefully.

• Read the question carefully.

• Think about how the question relates to the passage(s).

• Organize your ideas on scratch paper. Use a thought map or outline to plan your essay.

• Plan to include multiple paragraphs in your essay.

FOCUS while you write
• Analyze and explain what you think about the information from the passage(s) in your essay.

• Support and develop the ideas in your essay by using text evidence from the passage(s).

• Use correct language, a variety of sentence types, and transitions between paragraphs in your essay.

• Organize your essay with an introduction, body, and conclusion.

SubTopics: Appropriately use and explain the intended purpose in conventions with commas (introductory elements, and elements that need to be set off like a question or direct address).
Content: Read the sentence.
:ibox:When my brother and I get together with our two favorite cousins we have so much fun.
What is the correct way to write the sentence?

A.Choice: When my brother and I, get together with our two favorite cousins we have so much fun.

B.Choice: When my brother and I, get together with our two favorite cousins, we have so much fun.

C.Choice: When my brother and I get together with our two favorite cousins, we have so much fun.

D.Choice: When my brother and I get, together with our two favorite cousins, we have so much fun.

SubTopics: Opinion pieces that support a point of view about a topic or text clearly, state an opinion, and create an organizational structure in which ideas are logically ordered to support facts, details, and the writer's purpose.
Content: Read the paragraph.

:ibox:The Brooklyn Bridge is one of the most famous bridges in the United States. It stretches across the East River, linking the cities of New York and Brooklyn. The bridge took 600 workers more than 14 years to build; it was completed in the year 1883. About 150,000 people usually go over the Brooklyn Bridge.
How should the last sentence of the paragraph be rewritten to use the most precise language?

A.Choice: About 150,000 people use the bridge daily to cross to the other side of the river.

B.Choice: About 150,000 people walk, bike, or drive across the Brooklyn Bridge each day.

C.Choice: About 150,000 people use the bridge each day to cross the river.

D.Choice: About 150,000 people go across the river daily on the Brooklyn Bridge.

SubTopics: Recall relevant information from experiences or gather relevant information from print and digital sources, summarize or paraphrase information in notes and finished work, and provide a list of sources.
Content: A student is writing an essay about happiness. Read the student's draft and answer the question that follows.

:ibox:Did you know that there are scientists who study happiness? Daniel Gilbert, who is a professor at Harvard University, has spent years learning about what makes people happy. He has even written a popular book on the topic. His book Stumbling on Happiness discusses how challenging it is for people to know today what will make them happy in the future. He notes, though, that people are usually able to adapt to change much better than they think they can.

According to Gilbert, “We're not supposed to be happy all the time.” It's both normal and important to feel other types of emotions. We can appreciate happiness more if we don't always have it. As Gilbert says, “Happiness is a place to visit, not a place to live.” The next time you're feeling sad or even angry, remember that it is not really possible to always feel happy.
Which source would most likely offer the student the BEST additional information to include in the report?

A.Choice: an interview with Gilbert in which he answers questions about happiness

B.Choice: a short article that explains how Gilbert got a job teaching at Harvard University

C.Choice: an article written by one of Gilbert's students about how happy the student was having Gilbert as a teacher

D.Choice: a bookstore website that has a short review of Gilbert's book

SubTopics: Summarize the points a speaker makes and explain how each claim is supported by reasons and evidence.
Content: Which detail does the speaker use to show that the aye-aye sees well at night?

A.Choice: The aye-aye is able to recognize faint rays of moonlight.

B.Choice: The aye-aye has eyes that are especially large and glowing.

C.Choice: The aye-aye searches for snacks that are inside tree branches.

D.Choice: The aye-aye has eyes that look like those of an owl.

SubTopics: Summarize the points a speaker makes and explain how each claim is supported by reasons and evidence.
Content: Which details from the presentation support the speaker's claim that each of the aye-aye's unique features serves a purpose? Choose TWO answers.

A.Choice: The front teeth of the aye-aye never stop growing.

B.Choice: The aye-aye sleeps during the daytime and hunts at night.

C.Choice: The aye-aye uses its long finger to grab food.

D.Choice: The aye-aye likes to live in the rain forest.

E.Choice: The large ears of the aye-aye help it sense larvae.

SubTopics: Summarize a written text read aloud or information presented in diverse media and formats.
Content: Which sentence BEST summarizes the presentation?

A.Choice: The aye-aye spends a lot of time looking for food to eat.

B.Choice: The aye-aye has unusual body parts that help it to survive.

C.Choice: The aye-aye is a challenging animal for scientists to study.

D.Choice: The aye-aye lives in only one place on Earth.

SubTopics: Explain how a series of chapters, scenes, or stanzas fits together to determine the overall structure of a story, drama, or poem.
Content: How do paragraphs 1-6 of the passage MOST contribute to the development of the plot?

A.Choice: by showing how Leo and Troy prepare for the race differently

B.Choice: by explaining Leo's and Troy's reasons for participating in the race

C.Choice: by determining whether Leo or Troy is the better runner

D.Choice: by contrasting Leo's and Troy's usual running styles during a race

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words, phrases, figurative language, academic and content-specific words, and analyze their effect on meaning, tone, and mood within a text.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:ibox:“Be prepared, though, to be l͟e͟f͟t͟ ͟i͟n͟ ͟t͟h͟e͟ ͟d͟u͟s͟t by your speedy twin.”
What does Leo mean when he uses the phrase “left in the dust” in the sentence?

A.Choice: He thinks he practiced harder than Troy.

B.Choice: He thinks he will easily beat Troy.

C.Choice: He thinks Troy is going to be late for the race.

D.Choice: He thinks Troy will be forced to run in the dirt.

SubTopics: Summarize texts, from a variety of genres, to determine a theme or central idea and explain how it is supported by key details.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS. FIRST, ANSWER PART A. THEN, ANSWER PART B.
Which sentence BEST describes the lesson Leo learns in the passage?

A.Choice: Family members have more in common than they may realize.

B.Choice: Difficult times help us to better appreciate the happy times.

C.Choice: Good preparation today can make life easier in the future.

D.Choice: A sense of humor is one of the most important qualities to have.

Content: Which sentence from the passage BEST supports the answer in Part A?

A.Choice: “Yep, and I've been getting lots of running practice this week!”

B.Choice: “I know you've worked hard to get ready for it.”

C.Choice: “Hey, Troy, can you give me some help here?”

D.Choice: “Also, could you remind me to reset my alarm clock when we get home?”

SubTopics: Explain the relationships or interactions between two or more individuals, events, ideas, or concepts based on specific evidence from the text.
Content: Which idea helped Bertocchini and her team to think that the worms may have something on their bodies that breaks down the plastic?

A.Choice: the speed at which the worms were able to make holes in the plastic

B.Choice: the number of holes each worm made in the plastic in one hour

C.Choice: the fact that holes appeared in the plastic even if the worms were not alive

D.Choice: the idea that other types of worms may make holes in other types of plastic

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Explain how claims in a text are supported by relevant reasons and evidence, identifying which reasons and evidence support which claims.
Content: Read the paragraph from the passage.

:ibox:Bertocchini's research is promising. However, other scientists are doubtful. Ramani Narayan, a scientist from the University of Michigan, is one of them. He thinks that, if wax worms eat plastic, tiny pieces of plastic could work their way into the food chain. This plastic might then be harmful to other living things. He does not think that the worms are the answer to the problem of pollution.
Which sentences in the paragraph BEST support the idea that using worms to break down trash may be a bad idea? Choose TWO answers.

C.Choice: Ramani Narayan, a scientist from the University of Michigan, is one of them.

D.Choice: He thinks that, if wax worms eat plastic, tiny pieces of plastic could work their way into the food chain.

E.Choice: This plastic might then be harmful to other living things.

F.Choice: He does not think that the worms are the answer to the problem of pollution.

SubTopics: Explain the relationships or interactions between two or more individuals, events, ideas, or concepts based on specific evidence from the text.
Content: Which sentence from the passage BEST explains how the research about one topic may encourage research about other topics?

A.Choice: She and her team kept careful records of what happened.

B.Choice: More tests are needed, of course, before millions of wax worms can be added to landfills.

C.Choice: Scientists agree that Bertocchini may have come across an important finding.

D.Choice: Some scientists also wonder whether a similar solution might exist for plastic waste in the ocean.
